III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The House of Providence is located in Oxford Township, Michigan. The House of
Providence Girls facility is a new construction comprised of approximately 22 acres. It is a
ranch style home with a basement. The basement is used for storage. The parking area is
located on the west side of the facility. Primary access for the residents and staff is through
a side entrance door. Primary access for visitors is through the front entrance door. Upon
entering the front entrance, there is a kitchen, pantry and a dining room area. Off of the
dining room is a covered patio. The office area and one bathroom is located on the left side
of the kitchen. Medications are kept double-locked in a medication room in the office area.
A door, which can be locked, separates the office area and kitchen. The sleeping area for
the residents is located on the right side of the facility. There are five bedrooms each
containing two single beds, two dressers, a window and a closet. The residents’ bathroom is
next to the sleeping area. It contains five partitioned toilets, five partitioned shower stalls
and three sinks. The laundry room and sitting/entertainment area is located on the same
side as the sleeping area. All beds and furniture are new. The facility has been
professionally decorated with earthy colors and furnishings.
MDHHS, Division of Environment Health (DEH), Toxicology and Response Section (TARS)
completed a Letter Health Consultation (LHC). The LHC concluded that there is no
apparent public health hazard that would present a health risk to most future full-time
residents of the house built on 3791 Barber Road (parcel two), which is to be used as a
Child Caring Institution (CCI). Recommendations for use of a protective barrier on adjacent
parcels of land owned by the licensees were made and have been installed in the form of
snow fencing in the designated areas. Additional recommendations were made regarding
admission criteria for future residents and supervision of those residents, addressed later in
this report.
B. Program Description
The House of Providence Girls program was previously operated in Detroit, Michigan.
The policies and procedures essentially remain the same as the previous program, with
revisions made based on the recommendations from the LHC regarding admission
criteria for residents and supervision while residents are outside on the property.
The House of Providence Girls program is a non-secured residential treatment program
servicing a maximum of six female residents between the ages of seven and seventeen
years, who are abuse and neglect wards (temporary or permanent). The facility will
accept residents with general to moderate care requirements to include emotional and
behavioral issues with a range of cognitive level of functioning. House of Providence will
thoroughly examine residents’ medical records and will refrain from accepting youth
3

who have a diagnosis of PICA and those who have hyperparathyroidism. Further, they
will refrain from accepting youth who have a known elevated blood lead level.
Resident’s first choice of school will be through the Oxford Public Schools. The facility
will also use an accredited online charter school through Oxford Public Schools Virtual
Academy on a secondary basis. The virtual charter school will only be implemented
when a Family Team Meeting concludes that is the best option for the specific resident
and in compliance with DHHS policy. Tutoring will be available at the House of
Providence Girls. Services for the program will include but are not limited to individual
and group therapy, a variety of recreational activities, both on-grounds and off-grounds,
and social work services.
The facility will have a staff to resident ratio of one staff to four residents during wake
hours and one awake staff for every six residents during sleeping hours. Meals will be
prepared by staff. Staff has been certified in first aid and CPR. The facility will also
utilize Crisis Prevention Intervention as their behavior management system to include
proper and safe techniques of restraints. The facility will use local physicians and
dentists, as well as other specialists as deemed necessary.
Per the recommendation of the LHC, the following policies and procedures to minimize
lead exposure were developed:
 No House of Providence Girls residents will play, hike, walk, etc., to any other
parcel, other than the parcel that the licensed CCI is situated on. Staff will
supervise residents at all times when residents are outside of the home and will
redirect residents back inside if they go outside without permission. One to one
supervision staff to resident supervision will be utilized when needed.
 Properties will be properly maintained and will be appropriately covered with non-
edible ground covering, as much as is possible.
 Hand washing will continue to be a priority and a requirement for staff and
residents. Regular and weekly home cleaning will continue. This includes
dusting, vacuuming (HEPA filter system) and floor sanitation with the industrial
strength floor cleaning machine. The cleaning will continue to be done by staff
and any assistance that is given by residents will be minimal (less than staff’s
responsibilities) and given strict oversight.
 In order to minimize tracking of dirt and dust, they will continue with their “no
shoes in the home” policy. Separate shoes will be kept for indoors and outdoors.
Doormats and welcome mats will also be utilized to clean shoes’ surface prior to
entering the home.
 They will not garden on the campus in Oxford for anything edible or that will be
for human consumption. Flower gardens are permitted. Any fruit bearing trees
will have the fruit washed thoroughly before consumption.
 All walking paths on the property will be properly scraped prior to usage.
 Any livestock will only be permitted on areas of the property where all lead levels
are below required testing.
 If a play structure is planned, the agency will seek DCWL approval prior to
building and placing such a structure.
4

Facility policies and procedures have been reviewed and have been found to be in
compliance with State of Michigan licensing rules and applicable statutes.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are no violations.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that this child caring institution be issued an original license.
